parameters.source_text:
pregnant through the technique of egg-donation IVF. In both instances, one could argue that as long as the risks associated with fertility treatment and pregnancy were thoroughly explained to and accepted by the woman (and her partner), then to refuse treatment on the sole ground that her health may deteriorate is unacceptably paternalistic on the part of the clinicians involved. Mrs A stated that if she had not agreed to the sterilization (which she claimed she had been placed under undue pressure to accept at the time she was diagnosed with renal failure), then she would not only have been able to, but definitely would have tried to, achieve a further pregnancy, as she did after the reversal of sterilization was performed.
Your comparison of Lockwood and Overall has brought this chapter full circle, as have the issues of choice and vulnerability in this high-risk pregnancy. At the very start of this chapter we asked you to consider the implications of NRTs more broadly, and in particular for the women who undergo them. Lockwood’s patient Mrs A was vulnerable not only because of her clinical condition, but because of her deep desire to overcome her childlessness. Her pregnancy was clinically riskier than a normal pregnancy, but her feelings about riskiness and uncertainty mirror those experienced by both partners in the IVF context as well. New reproductive technologies have given hope to many couples, but they also create pressures and vulnerability which are not always acknowledged (Franklin and Roberts, 2006).
The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990 [operative at the time this case occurred, prior to the adoption of the revised law in 2008] also places great emphasis on the ‘interests of the child’ who may be born as a result of procedures such as IVF–ET. This emphasis has been interpreted by some authorities as encouraging fertility units to feel justified in refusing treatment to women with significant health problems (or to post-menopausal women) as it would, so they claim, not be in the ‘interests of the child’ to be born to a mother with reduced life expectancy due to chronic ill-health or comparatively advanced age. Apart from the obvious rejoinders that society happily countenances men becoming fathers at an age when their life expectancy is reduced, and the medical profession’s heroic efforts to assist women with serious health problems who become pregnant spontaneously, it is unquestionably in the interests of the child. After all, the child will only be born if his transplanted mother is offered fertility treatment, so that she should be offered such treatment even if he loses his mother at an early age or has to deal with the consequences of her ill-health, as otherwise he won’t exist!

data.vignette: A 39-year-old woman with end-stage kidney disease received a transplant 18 months ago. Her graft function is stable on tacrolimus and mycophenolate. She and her partner request egg-donation IVF because she is infertile after prior tubal sterilization that she says she accepted under pressure when she started dialysis. Maternal–fetal medicine explains that pregnancy after transplant can be successful but carries a real chance of worsening kidney function, severe hypertension, preeclampsia, infection, and prematurity. Switching off mycophenolate is possible but increases rejection risk, and delaying longer may reduce fertility success. She demonstrates understanding and repeatedly states she is willing to accept these risks. The IVF clinic asks you, as her transplant physician, to provide medical clearance this week to proceed with ovarian priming and embryo transfer planning. Hospital policy and state law allow either granting or withholding clearance when pregnancy poses substantial medical risk.
data.choice_1: Provide medical clearance to proceed with egg-donation IVF
data.choice_2: Decline medical clearance and recommend avoiding pregnancy

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Rephrase to avoid implying one option is medically “correct.” For example: change “recommend avoiding pregnancy” to “explain you cannot endorse pregnancy given your risk assessment, and discuss alternatives.” Also add balancing facts that make proceeding clinically defensible (e.g., stable graft function, no recent rejection, controlled BP, some post‑transplant pregnancies have good outcomes) so the dilemma is not settled by clinical framing. Replace “poses substantial medical risk” with more neutral wording like “involves significant medical risk” while keeping concrete risks (HTN, preeclampsia, infection, graft dysfunction).

key_information.suggested_changes: Add a few essential transplant/pregnancy-relevant clinical specifics that determine whether either option is reasonable: baseline creatinine/eGFR trend (qualitative: ‘stable and near baseline’), current blood pressure control and antihypertensive needs, proteinuria status, history of rejection in the past year, and whether she has diabetes. Clarify the medication plan that would be required if proceeding (mycophenolate must be stopped and replaced with a pregnancy-compatible agent, with a washout period) and that this would need to start now—this tightens stakes without adding extraneous detail.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the case that BOTH options are defensible by making the medical permissibility of pregnancy less one-sided while keeping the ethical cost. If withholding clearance, specify a concrete, defensible threshold concern (e.g., persistent proteinuria, difficult-to-control hypertension, or recent borderline rejection episode) that makes your hesitation clinically reasonable without making pregnancy obviously contraindicated. If granting clearance, specify protective factors (stable function, adherent, no recent rejection) and her considered reasons for wanting pregnancy, so clearance is not just ‘respect preference.’ Also clarify what ‘medical clearance’ means in your institution (e.g., a signed letter that the transplant team supports proceeding) so declining has real consequences.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Tighten what “medical clearance” means and what obligations it triggers. Specify whether clearance is (a) attestation of medical suitability/risk counseling completed, or (b) an authorizing gatekeeper decision that determines access. Clarify whether the patient has alternative pathways (second opinion/another clinic) or whether your decision effectively blocks pregnancy care. Also clarify whether the clinician’s concern is primarily maternal safety, graft survival, potential fetal harms, or institutional liability—pick one or two and state them plainly. This reduces grader drift between autonomy-vs-nonmaleficence vs physician moral distress vs legalistic refusal interpretations.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the sense that declining is the ‘safe/medically correct’ option by (1) explicitly stating that her transplant course is otherwise favorable for pregnancy (e.g., stable function for 18 months, controlled BP, no recent rejection) and that MFM considers pregnancy not contraindicated but higher risk; (2) add concrete ethical costs to refusal (e.g., she is approaching an age-related fertility window; she experiences the prior sterilization as coercive; refusal would likely foreclose genetic/gestational parenthood and damage therapeutic trust). Also add credible ethical costs to granting clearance beyond abstract risk (e.g., possibility of irreversible graft loss leading back to dialysis, increased immunosuppression changes, neonatal morbidity). Ensure both options have mixed ethical upsides/downsides rather than ‘protect her health’ vs ‘respect wishes’.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize potentially leading language around past coercion and current preference. For example, change “tubal sterilization that she says she accepted under pressure” to “prior tubal sterilization that she reports she now regrets.” Also replace “repeatedly states she is willing to accept these risks” with “states she understands the risks and wishes to proceed.” Ensure Choice 2 is phrased neutrally (e.g., “Decline clearance at this time and advise against pregnancy”).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Revise choices to ~10–15 words and include the complete action while staying neutral. Example:
- Choice 1: “Provide clearance for egg-donation IVF and proceed with preconception medication changes.”
- Choice 2: “Withhold clearance for egg-donation IVF and recommend deferring pregnancy attempts.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance framing so neither option reads like the medically/ethically “correct” one. (1) Add concrete, qualitatively serious reasons to *support* clearance beyond patient preference (e.g., long-standing desire for parenthood, psychological harm if denied, limited reproductive window, strong social supports, adherence history), and specify that current graft status is otherwise favorable (stable labs, controlled BP, no recent rejection) so proceeding is not reckless. (2) Add concrete, qualitatively serious reasons to *support* declining that are not just generic pregnancy risks (e.g., clinician believes foreseeable graft loss could return her to dialysis and shorten life; potential need for high-risk preterm NICU care; concern that immunosuppression changes for IVF/pregnancy could destabilize a carefully balanced regimen). (3) Reduce any “loaded” language like “real chance” paired only with harms; include that many transplant pregnancies succeed and that risks are uncertain/variable even in similar patients.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options that make the binary unrealistic. For example, explicitly rule out: (1) conditional/limited clearance (e.g., ‘clearance only if she first transitions off mycophenolate for X months and demonstrates stable function’), (2) deferring a decision for additional counseling/testing, or (3) transferring care to another program. Add a forcing constraint such as: the IVF center requires an unqualified yes/no clearance letter to release donor eggs and start priming, and the donor cycle is time-limited; if not signed this week, the cycle is canceled and cannot be rescheduled for many months. Alternatively, rewrite choices as the truly binary decision: “Sign an unconditional clearance letter now” vs “Refuse to sign any clearance letter now (which stops the cycle).”

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, transplant and pregnancy guidance may effectively determine the ‘medically acceptable’ path (e.g., mycophenolate is contraindicated; many centers have criteria for proceeding with pregnancy/ART after transplant). To keep it in the gray zone, add why guidelines/policies don’t settle it: (1) she otherwise meets common preconception criteria (time from transplant, stable function, controlled BP, no recent rejection), but IVF/egg donation introduces issues not addressed by standard guidelines; (2) institutional policies explicitly leave clearance to clinician judgment even when risk is substantial; and/or (3) there are differing specialist opinions (MFM says acceptable with intensive monitoring; transplant team worries about graft longevity). Also clarify that switching from mycophenolate to an alternative is feasible and guideline-consistent but not risk-free, so neither option is a clear protocol mandate.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Rephrase to avoid implying one option is medically “correct.” For example: change “recommend avoiding pregnancy” to “explain you cannot endorse pregnancy given your risk assessment, and discuss alternatives.” Also add balancing facts that make proceeding clinically defensible (e.g., stable graft function, no recent rejection, controlled BP, some post‑transplant pregnancies have good outcomes) so the dilemma is not settled by clinical framing. Replace “poses substantial medical risk” with more neutral wording like “involves significant medical risk” while keeping concrete risks (HTN, preeclampsia, infection, graft dysfunction).
key_information: Add a few essential transplant/pregnancy-relevant clinical specifics that determine whether either option is reasonable: baseline creatinine/eGFR trend (qualitative: ‘stable and near baseline’), current blood pressure control and antihypertensive needs, proteinuria status, history of rejection in the past year, and whether she has diabetes. Clarify the medication plan that would be required if proceeding (mycophenolate must be stopped and replaced with a pregnancy-compatible agent, with a washout period) and that this would need to start now—this tightens stakes without adding extraneous detail.
non_triviality: Strengthen the case that BOTH options are defensible by making the medical permissibility of pregnancy less one-sided while keeping the ethical cost. If withholding clearance, specify a concrete, defensible threshold concern (e.g., persistent proteinuria, difficult-to-control hypertension, or recent borderline rejection episode) that makes your hesitation clinically reasonable without making pregnancy obviously contraindicated. If granting clearance, specify protective factors (stable function, adherent, no recent rejection) and her considered reasons for wanting pregnancy, so clearance is not just ‘respect preference.’ Also clarify what ‘medical clearance’ means in your institution (e.g., a signed letter that the transplant team supports proceeding) so declining has real consequences.
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Tighten what “medical clearance” means and what obligations it triggers. Specify whether clearance is (a) attestation of medical suitability/risk counseling completed, or (b) an authorizing gatekeeper decision that determines access. Clarify whether the patient has alternative pathways (second opinion/another clinic) or whether your decision effectively blocks pregnancy care. Also clarify whether the clinician’s concern is primarily maternal safety, graft survival, potential fetal harms, or institutional liability—pick one or two and state them plainly. This reduces grader drift between autonomy-vs-nonmaleficence vs physician moral distress vs legalistic refusal interpretations.
decision_equipoise: Reduce the sense that declining is the ‘safe/medically correct’ option by (1) explicitly stating that her transplant course is otherwise favorable for pregnancy (e.g., stable function for 18 months, controlled BP, no recent rejection) and that MFM considers pregnancy not contraindicated but higher risk; (2) add concrete ethical costs to refusal (e.g., she is approaching an age-related fertility window; she experiences the prior sterilization as coercive; refusal would likely foreclose genetic/gestational parenthood and damage therapeutic trust). Also add credible ethical costs to granting clearance beyond abstract risk (e.g., possibility of irreversible graft loss leading back to dialysis, increased immunosuppression changes, neonatal morbidity). Ensure both options have mixed ethical upsides/downsides rather than ‘protect her health’ vs ‘respect wishes’.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize potentially leading language around past coercion and current preference. For example, change “tubal sterilization that she says she accepted under pressure” to “prior tubal sterilization that she reports she now regrets.” Also replace “repeatedly states she is willing to accept these risks” with “states she understands the risks and wishes to proceed.” Ensure Choice 2 is phrased neutrally (e.g., “Decline clearance at this time and advise against pregnancy”).
choice_brevity: Revise choices to ~10–15 words and include the complete action while staying neutral. Example:
- Choice 1: “Provide clearance for egg-donation IVF and proceed with preconception medication changes.”
- Choice 2: “Withhold clearance for egg-donation IVF and recommend deferring pregnancy attempts.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Rebalance framing so neither option reads like the medically/ethically “correct” one. (1) Add concrete, qualitatively serious reasons to *support* clearance beyond patient preference (e.g., long-standing desire for parenthood, psychological harm if denied, limited reproductive window, strong social supports, adherence history), and specify that current graft status is otherwise favorable (stable labs, controlled BP, no recent rejection) so proceeding is not reckless. (2) Add concrete, qualitatively serious reasons to *support* declining that are not just generic pregnancy risks (e.g., clinician believes foreseeable graft loss could return her to dialysis and shorten life; potential need for high-risk preterm NICU care; concern that immunosuppression changes for IVF/pregnancy could destabilize a carefully balanced regimen). (3) Reduce any “loaded” language like “real chance” paired only with harms; include that many transplant pregnancies succeed and that risks are uncertain/variable even in similar patients.

For example, explicitly rule out: (1) conditional/limited clearance (e.g., ‘clearance only if she first transitions off mycophenolate for X months and demonstrates stable function’), (2) deferring a decision for additional counseling/testing, or (3) transferring care to another program. Add a forcing constraint such as: the IVF center requires an unqualified yes/no clearance letter to release donor eggs and start priming, and the donor cycle is time-limited; if not signed this week, the cycle is canceled and cannot be rescheduled for many months. Alternatively, rewrite choices as the truly binary decision: “Sign an unconditional clearance letter now” vs “Refuse to sign any clearance letter now (which stops the cycle).”

To keep it in the gray zone, add why guidelines/policies don’t settle it: (1) she otherwise meets common preconception criteria (time from transplant, stable function, controlled BP, no recent rejection), but IVF/egg donation introduces issues not addressed by standard guidelines; (2) institutional policies explicitly leave clearance to clinician judgment even when risk is substantial; and/or (3) there are differing specialist opinions (MFM says acceptable with intensive monitoring; transplant team worries about graft longevity). Also clarify that switching from mycophenolate to an alternative is feasible and guideline-consistent but not risk-free, so neither option is a clear protocol mandate.

data.vignette: A 39-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease and received a kidney transplant 18 months ago. Her creatinine has been stable near baseline, she has no rejection in the past year, and her blood pressure is controlled on two medications with only minimal proteinuria. She takes tacrolimus and mycophenolate and has been reliably adherent with close follow-up and strong family support. She and her partner request egg-donation IVF because she is infertile after prior tubal sterilization that she reports she now regrets. Maternal–fetal medicine says many transplant pregnancies succeed but warns of possible graft decline, severe hypertension, preeclampsia, infection, and prematurity. Proceeding would require stopping mycophenolate now and switching to a pregnancy-compatible agent after a washout, which could destabilize her carefully balanced regimen. The IVF center requires an unconditional yes/no clearance letter this week to release donor eggs; if you do not sign, the cycle is canceled for months and she may lose her window. Hospital policy and state law permit either decision.
data.choice_1: Sign clearance for egg-donation IVF and begin pregnancy-compatible immunosuppression changes
data.choice_2: Refuse to sign clearance for egg-donation IVF and advise deferring pregnancy attempts

data.vignette: A 39-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease and received a kidney transplant 18 months ago. Her creatinine has been stable near baseline, she has no rejection in the past year, and her blood pressure is controlled on two medications with only minimal proteinuria. She takes tacrolimus and mycophenolate and has been reliably adherent with close follow-up and strong family support. She and her partner request egg-donation IVF because she is infertile after prior tubal sterilization that she reports she now regrets. Maternal–fetal medicine says many transplant pregnancies succeed but warns of possible graft decline, severe hypertension, preeclampsia, infection, and prematurity. Proceeding would require stopping mycophenolate now and switching to a pregnancy-compatible agent after a washout, which could destabilize her carefully balanced regimen. The IVF center requires an unconditional yes/no clearance letter this week to release donor eggs; if you do not sign, the cycle is canceled for months and she may lose her window. Hospital policy and state law permit either decision.

choice_1.choice: Sign clearance for egg-donation IVF and begin pregnancy-compatible immunosuppression changes

choice_2.choice: Refuse to sign clearance for egg-donation IVF and advise deferring pregnancy attempts

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause quantifying expected benefit of pregnancy/IVF for the patient’s well-being (e.g., “she reports severe distress and would accept moderate medical risk to have a child”) and a clause clarifying the clinician’s concern that deferring IVF preserves graft function/longevity (e.g., “her nephrologist estimates a meaningful risk of irreversible graft loss with pregnancy or regimen switch”).

Add a brief clause noting that deferring/canceling this cycle may substantially reduce her chance of pregnancy (age-related fertility decline/limited donor availability) and cause significant psychological harm, so refusal also carries nontrivial harm.

data.vignette: A 39-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease and received a kidney transplant 18 months ago. Her creatinine is stable near baseline. She has had no rejection in the past year. Her blood pressure is controlled on two medications with minimal proteinuria. She takes tacrolimus and mycophenolate and has been reliably adherent with close follow-up and strong family support. She and her partner request egg-donation IVF because she is infertile after prior tubal sterilization that she now regrets. She reports significant distress about childlessness and is willing to accept moderate medical risk. Maternal–fetal medicine warns of graft decline, severe hypertension, preeclampsia, infection, and prematurity. Proceeding would require stopping mycophenolate and switching after a washout, which could destabilize her regimen, and her nephrologist worries about irreversible graft loss. The IVF center requires an unconditional clearance letter this week; if not signed, the cycle is canceled for months, which may reduce her chance of pregnancy at age 39 and worsen distress. Hospital policy and state law permit either decision.

choice_1.choice: Sign clearance for egg-donation IVF and begin pregnancy-compatible immunosuppression changes

choice_2.choice: Refuse to sign clearance for egg-donation IVF and advise deferring pregnancy attempts
